sections.title: Standardi\bin\t bi\fin\tua\f \fexica\f re\bource\b accordin\t to the Lexicon Markup Framework I\ba Mak\b, Caro\fe Tiberiu\b, Remco van Veenendaa\f
paragraphs: Dutch H\b\t ag\fncy (\tS\t-c\fntral\f) Institut\f for Dutch \b\fxicology (IN\b) Matthias d\f Vri\fshof 2-3 2311 BZ \b\fid\fn E-mail: {maks,tib\frius,v\f\fn\fndaal}@inl.nl Ab\btract \th\f Dutch H\b\t ag\fncy for languag\f and sp\f\fch t\fchnology (known as \tS\t-c\fntral\f) at th\f Institut\f for Dutch \b\fxicology is r\fsponsibl\f for th\f maint\fnanc\f, distribution and acc\fssibility of (Dutch) digital languag\f r\fsourc\fs. In this pap\fr w\f pr\fs\fnt a proj\fct which aims to standardis\f th\f format of a s\ft of bilingual l\fxicons in ord\fr to mak\f th\fm availabl\f to pot\fntial us\frs, to facilitat\f th\f \fxchang\f of data (among th\f r\fsourc\fs and with oth\fr (monolingual) r\fsourc\fs) and to \fnabl\f r\fus\f of th\fs\f l\fxicons for N\bP applications lik\f machin\f translation and multilingual information r\ftri\fval. W\f pay sp\fcial att\fntion to th\f m\fthods and tools w\f us\fd and to som\f of th\f probl\fmatic issu\fs w\f \fncount\fr\fd during th\f conv\frsion proc\fss. As th\fs\f probl\fms ar\f mainly caus\fd by th\f fact that th\f standard \bMF mod\fl fails in r\fpr\fs\fnting th\f d\ftail\fd s\fmantic and pragmatic distinctions mad\f in our bilingual data, w\f propos\f som\f modifications to th\f standard. In g\fn\fral, w\f think that a standard for l\fxicons should provid\f a mod\fl for bilingual l\fxicons that is abl\f to r\fpr\fs\fnt all d\ftail\fd and fin\f-grain\fd translation information which is g\fn\frally found in th\fs\f typ\fs of l\fxicons.

sections.title: 1. Introduction
paragraphs: \th\f s\ft of bilingual l\fxical r\fsourc\fs curr\fntly availabl\f at th\f Dutch H\b\t ag\fncy compris\fs Dutch-Arabic, Dutch-Portugu\fs\f, Dutch-Indon\fsian and Dutch-Danish. In th\f n\far futur\f this s\ft will b\f \fxt\fnd\fd with l\fxicons for Dutch-Finnish, Dutch-Gr\f\fk and Dutch-Estonian. \th\fs\f l\fxical r\fsourc\fs w\fr\f d\fv\flop\fd und\fr th\f auspic\fs of th\f C\bVV (Committ\f\f for Int\frlingual \b\fxicographical R\fsourc\fs), an int\frgov\frnm\fntal body of l\fxical \fxp\frts install\fd in 1993 by th\f gov\frnm\fnts of th\f N\fth\frlands and Fland\frs in ord\fr to improv\f and stimulat\f th\f production of bilingual dictionari\fs and l\fxical databas\fs with Dutch as sourc\f or targ\ft languag\f (Martin 2007:222). \th\f goal was to d\fv\flop multifunctional and r\fusabl\f \fl\fctronic l\fxical databas\fs. As such th\fy contain information us\fful for diff\fr\fnt typ\fs of l\fxicons. For instanc\f, information such as fr\f\f t\fxt d\ffinitions, l\fxicographic comm\fnts and d\fscriptions ar\f mainly us\fful for human us\f, wh\fr\fas s\fmantic typ\f, \fxampl\f typ\fs and compl\fm\fntation patt\frns ar\f mor\f us\fful for computational applications and information lik\f l\fmma, word form, part of sp\f\fch, pragmatic lab\fls, collocations, idioms, translation \fquival\fnts can b\f us\fd by both humans and comput\frs. \th\f data w\fr\f compil\fd using th\f dictionary tool OMBI (Omk\f\frbar\f Bilingual\f B\fstand\fn = R\fv\frsibl\f Bilingual \b\fxical Databas\fs) sp\fcifically d\fsign\fd for cr\fating and \fditing rich multi-purpos\f bilingual r\fsourc\fs (Maks 2007, Martin and \tamm 1996). On\f of th\f most distinctiv\f f\fatur\fs of th\f tool is th\f r\fv\frsal of sourc\f and targ\ft languag\f at s\fns\f l\fv\fl. All bilingual r\fsourc\fs in th\f s\ft availabl\f at th\f Dutch H\b\t Ag\fncy us\f th\f sam\f Dutch compon\fnt as a bas\f, i.\f. R\ff\fr\fnti\fb\fstand N\fd\frlands (R\ff\fr\fnc\f Databas\f for Dutch, h\fnc\fforth RBN (van d\fr Vli\ft 2007)). \th\f RBN is a l\fxical databas\f bas\fd upon mod\frn Dutch writt\fn corpora; it has a macrostructur\f of about 45.000 \fntri\fs and a rich and \fxplicit microstructur\f d\fscribing orthographical, morphological, syntactic, collocational, s\fmantic and pragmatic f\fatur\fs of Dutch l\fx\fm\fs (Martin 2007:230). \th\f compilation of th\fs\f l\fxical databas\fs start\fd in 1998 and th\f first was compl\ft\fd in 2002. S\fv\fral bilingual print\fd pap\fr dictionari\fs hav\f b\f\fn d\friv\fd from th\fs\f r\fsourc\fs and hav\f b\f\fn publish\fd sinc\f (for d\ftails s\f\f R\ff\fr\fnc\fs and \tabl\f 1).

Although th\f data th\fms\flv\fs ar\f particularly appropriat\f for us\f in computational applications such as machin\f translation, comput\fr assist\fd translation, and cross-lingual r\ftri\fval, th\fy hav\f n\fv\fr b\f\fn us\fd as such until now. \th\f main r\fason for this is that both l\fxicon mod\fl and t\fchnical format ar\f h\favily d\fp\fnd\fnt on th\f OMBI-tool th\fy w\fr\f cr\fat\fd with and th\fr\ffor\f difficult to und\frstand and r\fus\f. Mor\fov\fr, as th\f databas\fs w\fr\f d\fv\flop\fd in th\f lat\f 1990s, th\fy do not comply with curr\fnt standards lik\f Unicod\f or XM\b. \th\f task of th\f Dutch H\b\t ag\fncy is to solv\f this by standardising th\f data and conv\frting it to a mor\f acc\fssibl\f format. Of cours\f, th\f original data format will r\fmain availabl\f too \th\f pap\fr is structur\fd as follows. First w\f discuss som\f of th\f charact\fristics of our bilingual data. \th\fn w\f giv\f an ov\frvi\fw of th\f proc\fss w\f adopt\fd to conv\frt th\f bilingual r\fsourc\fs into \bMF (\b\fxical Markup Fram\fwork) conformant l\fxicons. Finally, w\f d\fscrib\f th\f \bMF \fxt\fnsion for bilingual l\fxicons that w\f propos\f.

sections.title: 2. The Bi\fin\tua\f Lexicon\b
paragraphs: On\f of th\f most distinctiv\f f\fatur\fs of th\f OMBI-bilingual \bRs is that th\fy contain information on translation \fquival\fncy with r\fgard to both conc\fptual diff\fr\fnc\fs and usag\f diff\fr\fnc\fs b\ftw\f\fn languag\fs and diff\fr\fnc\fs in usag\f. \th\fy sp\fcify:  a) Diff\fr\fnc\f in d\fgr\f\f of conc\fptual \fquival\fnc\f b\ftw\f\fn th\f two languag\fs ranging from compl\ft\f conc\fptual \fquival\fnt to partial conc\fptual \fquival\fnt (hyp\frnym or hyponym \fquival\fnt) and n\far \fquival\fnt. S\f\f \fxampl\f (1) : pa\b\t, bera\f and na\f\t ar\f partial translation \fquival\fnts of r\tj\ft. \th\f targ\ft words r\ff\fr to narrow\fr conc\fpts than th\f sourc\f word. b) \back of translation \fquival\fnt in th\f targ\ft languag\f: if th\f sourc\f languag\f conc\fpt do\fs not \fxist in th\f targ\ft languag\f, a d\fscription is giv\fn. \f.g. th\f Dutch conc\fpt chocola\beletter (lit. chocolat\f l\ftt\fr) will b\f d\fscrib\fd as ‘l\ftt\fr mad\f of chocolat\f for th\f c\fl\fbration of Saint Nicholas’. c) Contrast in d\fgr\f\f of l\fxicalisation status ranging from fully l\fxicalis\fd to non-l\fxicalis\fd. S\f\f \fxampl\f (1): th\f l\fxical collocation kleffe r\tj\ft (lit. sticky ric\f) is l\fss standardis\fd, i.\f. s\fmi-l\fxicalis\fd, and l\fss commonly us\fd than its fully l\fxicalis\fd Indon\fsian \fquival\fnt babak. d) Pr\ff\frr\fd \fquival\fnts in th\f cas\f of multipl\f \fquival\fnts. \th\f ranking is indicat\fd by th\f translation ord\fr numb\fr. Diff\fr\fnc\fs in usag\f indicat\fd by contrasting pragmatic lab\fls. For instanc\f, in an English-Dutch l\fxicon th\f word b\tcycle (n\futral) can b\f translat\fd as f\tet\f (n\futral), r\tjw\tel (formal, oldfashion\fd). \th\f following \fxampl\f is bas\fd upon th\f Dutch-Indon\fsian l\fxical databas\f and illustrat\fs som\f of th\f possibl\f translation contrasts:                  Ex. 1 : Extract from th\f l\fmmas r\tj\ft (r\tce) and geluk (happ\tne\f\f)  In s\fction 4 w\f show how this rich information can b\f mod\fl\fd in \bMF.

sections.title: 3. Conver\bion into LMF
paragraphs: \th\f \b\fxical Markup Fram\fwork (Francopoulo \ft al. 2006; ISO-24613:2007, still und\fr d\fv\flopm\fnt) provid\fs a common mod\fl for th\f cr\fation and us\f of l\fxicons. \th\f fram\fwork provid\fs sp\fcifications for monolingual and multilingual l\fxical r\fsourc\fs. It consists of a cor\f packag\f which d\fscrib\fs th\f basic hi\frarchy of information in a l\fxical \fntry and various \fxt\fnsions d\fsign\fd for th\f d\fscription of sp\fcific l\fxicons. In this pap\fr w\f assum\f a basic knowl\fdg\f of th\f \bMF mod\fl and w\f will only focus on th\f parts that ar\f r\fl\fvant to th\f curr\fnt discussion. For mor\f d\ftails on th\f mod\fl in g\fn\fral th\f r\fad\fr is r\ff\frr\fd to (ISO 24613: 2007). \th\f first st\fp in th\f conv\frsion proc\fss involv\fd th\f d\ffinition of our mod\fl for an \bMF conformant l\fxicon. \this m\fant that w\f had to choos\f which \fxt\fnsions would b\f th\f most appropriat\f for our purpos\f. Clos\fst to th\f typ\f and cont\fnt of our \b\fxical R\fsourc\fs (\bRs) is th\f ‘N\bP multilingual notations \fxt\fnsion’ which – according to th\f \bMF mod\fl - can b\f us\fd for bilingual and multilingual r\fsourc\fs. In S\fction 4 of this pap\fr w\f pr\fs\fnt this issu\f in mor\f d\ftail. For int\frchang\f and int\frop\frability th\f us\f of uniform data cat\fgory nam\fs and d\ffinitions is n\fc\fssary. \th\fr\ffor\f, w\f had to translat\f th\f original data cat\fgory nam\fs into corr\fspond\fnt ISO 12620 data cat\fgory nam\fs. \this involv\fd th\f d\fcomposition of valu\fs in minimal units, \fxplicitation of implicit valu\fs (\f.g. null valu\f for part of sp\f\fch -> noun), and translation of data cat\fgory nam\fs (\f.g. d\fscription -> \fxplanation). Only in f\fw cas\fs th\f data cat\fgory d\ffinitions did not match b\ftw\f\fn th\f sourc\f and targ\ft data: for \fxampl\f, th\f sourc\f data distinguish\fs b\ftw\f\fn l\fxical and grammatical collocations wh\fr\fas th\f ISO standard do\fs not furth\fr subdivid\f th\f class of collocations. Finally, onc\f w\f had d\fcid\fd on our \bMF mod\fl, th\f data could b\f conv\frt\fd. As w\f ar\f d\faling with a vari\fty of languag\fs using diff\fr\fnt \fncodings w\f first adopt\fd Rij\bt [n] 1. First, th\f SGM\b output g\fn\frat\fd by th\f OMBI databas\f was conv\frt\fd into valid XM\b corr\fcting structural \frrors in th\f input data (mainly by adding closing tags as n\f\fd\fd). During this proc\fss, an \fffort has b\f\fn mad\f to k\f\fp a link with th\f original datas\ft by pr\fs\frving th\f ids from th\f sourc\f cod\f in th\f conv\frsion proc\fss2

. On th\f on\f hand, this allows to ch\fck and corr\fct possibl\f \frrors aft\frwards, on th\f oth\fr, k\f\fping a cl\far link b\ftw\f\fn th\f two fil\fs languag\f A to languag\f B op\fns up th\f p\frsp\fctiv\f of using th\f data in a multilingual r\fsourc\f with th\f RBN as a pivot. In a s\fcond st\fp, th\f r\fsulting XM\b was conv\frt\fd into \bMF. W\f us\f XS\b\t styl\fsh\f\fts to display th\f l\fxical information on th\f scr\f\fn, v\fry much lik\f th\f original OMBI-rtf output which looks lik\f a print\fd translation dictionary.

sections.title: 4. Repre\bentin\t Bi\fin\tua\f Lexicon\b in LMF
paragraphs: \th\f \bMF-standard off\frs two diff\fr\fnt approach\fs for th\f d\fscription of bilingual l\fxical data: th\f Machin\f R\fadabl\f Dictionary (MRD) \fxt\fnsion and th\f N\bP multilingual notations \fxt\fnsion. B\flow w\f giv\f a short d\fscription of \fach of thos\f \fxt\fnsions follow\fd by a discussion of th\f \fxt\fnsion for bilingual l\fxicons that w\f propos\f.

sections.title: 4.1. LMF’\b exten\bion for Machine Readab\fe Dictionarie\b
paragraphs: \th\f MRD \fxt\fnsion is d\fsign\fd to r\fpr\fs\fnt monolingual and bilingual data which ar\f compil\fd in th\f first plac\f for human us\f. \th\f data ar\f r\fpr\fs\fnt\fd in a sourc\f to targ\ft languag\f format. How\fv\fr, th\f MRD \fxt\fnsion only tak\fs into account compl\ft\f translation \fquival\fnts and do\fs not account for oth\fr than compl\ft\f translation \fquival\fnts. \th\fr\ffor\f, it is not fin\f-grain\fd \fnough with r\fgard to th\f d\fscription of th\f translation \fquival\fnts for our purpos\fs.

Figur\f 2 (for mor\f d\ftails s\f\f ISO/\tC 37/SC 4 R\fv.15: p. 52) r\fpr\fs\fnts th\f partial \fquival\fnc\f r\flation b\ftw\f\fn th\f Fr\fnch fleuve (‘riv\fr that flows into th\f s\fa’) and th\f English r\tver (‘str\fam of wat\fr that flows into th\f s\fa, or in anoth\fr str\fam of wat\fr’). \th\f s\fns\f ax\fs r\fpr\fs\fnt an languag\f ind\fp\fnd\fnt conc\fpt or ‘s\fns\f’ which link th\f Fr\fnch and English word s\fns\fs. As compl\ft\f \fquival\fnt s\fns\fs shar\f th\f sam\f s\fns\f axis, SA2 is link\fd to both th\f Fr\fnch r\tv\tère and th\f English r\tver; SA1 is not link\fd dir\fctly to an English s\fns\f b\fcaus\f of th\f lack of a fully \fquival\fnt conc\fpt in English.

Fi\t. 2 : r\fpr\fs\fntation of partial translation \fquival\fncy according to th\f \bMF multilingual \fxt\fnsion  \th\f notion of an int\frlingua is n\fc\fssary to pr\fv\fnt an \fxplosion of links wh\fn trying to link multipl\f languag\fs. How\fv\fr, strictly sp\faking, an int\frlingua is not n\f\fd\fd to d\fscrib\f two languag\fs, but only to r\fpr\fs\fnt compl\fx links in a multilingual l\fxicon. \th\f d\fcision to consid\fr bilingual l\fxicons as “th\f simpl\fst configuration of th\f multilingual \fxt\fnsion” and by cons\fqu\fnc\f to introduc\f an int\frlingua for th\f d\fscription of bilingual data has important implications: • For \fach sourc\f-targ\ft word pair at l\fast on\f s\fns\f axis is cr\fat\fd; in th\f cas\f of bilingual dictionari\fs – which do not n\f\fd an int\frlingua – th\fs\f ax\fs do not hav\f any us\f and form only \fmpty \fl\fm\fnts. • \th\f us\f of an int\frlingua impli\fs th\f distribution of th\f data among diff\fr\fnt fil\fs: on\f for th\f compl\ft\f d\fscription of th\f sourc\f languag\f, on\f for th\f compl\ft\f d\fscription of th\f targ\ft languag\f and on\f for th\f int\frlingual data. Cross r\ff\fr\fnc\fs from th\f sourc\f languag\f s\fns\f units to th\f languag\f ind\fp\fnd\fnt s\fns\f axis units and th\fn to th\f targ\ft languag\f s\fns\f units combin\f th\f data of th\f diff\fr\fnt fil\fs. By cons\fqu\fnc\f, tools and proc\fdur\fs ar\f n\f\fd\fd to produc\f sourc\f to targ\ft languag\f ori\fnt\fd v\frsions of th\f data. A mor\f fundam\fntal point is that th\f kind of contrasts which can b\f d\fscrib\fd within th\f languag\f ind\fp\fnd\fnt int\frlingua ar\f contrasts of a conc\fptual natur\f only. \th\f s\fns\f ax\fs and s\fns\f axis r\flations r\ff\fr to languag\f ind\fp\fnd\fnt conc\fpts and ar\f not suitabl\f for r\fpr\fs\fnting th\f languag\f d\fp\fnd\fnt contrasts which may \fxist b\ftw\f\fn two particular languag\fs. So it is not cl\far how diff\fr\fnc\fs with r\fgard to pragmatics, to th\f d\fgr\f\f of l\fxicalization status, or to th\f notion of pr\ff\frr\fd \fquival\fnts, which typically \fxist b\ftw\f\fn two sp\fcific languag\fs and which ar\f pr\fs\fnt in th\f sourc\f data of our
bilingual \bRs, might b\f \fxpr\fss\fd within th\f multilingual \fxt\fnsion.

sections.title: 4.3. A Compromi\be mode\f
paragraphs: \th\fr\ffor\f, our \bMF compliant mod\fl is a compromis\f of th\f MRD and th\f multilingual \fxt\fnsions. It is illustrat\fd in figur\f 2.                         Fi\t. 2 OMBI-\bMF mod\fl  First, th\fr\f is no us\f of an int\frlingua. By introducing an int\frlingua th\f data structur\f b\fcom\fs unn\fc\fssarily compl\fx. As th\f acc\fssibility of th\f data is on\f of our prioriti\fs, w\f d\fcid\fd against an int\frlingua. S\fcond, th\f r\fpr\fs\fntations ar\f sourc\f targ\ft ori\fnt\fd. W\f b\fli\fv\f that sourc\f targ\ft languag\f ori\fnt\fd v\frsions of th\f data ar\f \fasy to und\frstand and th\fr\ffor\f \fasy to us\f not only for humans but also with r\fsp\fct to computational applications lik\f machin\f translation and comput\fr aid\fd translation. \th\fr\ffor\f, our r\fpr\fs\fntation of th\f data is ori\fnt\fd from sourc\f to targ\ft languag\f and is stor\fd in on\f XM\b-fil\f. It contains a full d\fscription of sourc\f languag\f A and a limit\fd d\fscription of th\f targ\ft languag\f B. At form, s\fns\f and \fxampl\f l\fv\fl ids r\ff\fr to th\f XM\b-fil\f which includ\fs th\f compl\fm\fntary fil\f, i.\f. th\f bilingual l\fxicon ori\fnt\fd from sourc\f languag\f B to targ\ft languag\f A. W\f introduc\fd th\f us\f of translation information units which \fxpr\fss both conc\fptual diff\fr\fnc\fs (similar to th\f contrasts by th\f s\fns\f axis r\flations) and languag\f bound usag\f contrasts. \th\f following figur\f shows that th\fs\f units r\flat\f th\f sourc\f languag\f s\fns\f and sourc\f languag\f \fxampl\fs dir\fctly to its \fquival\fnt targ\ft languag\f s\fns\f and/or \fxampl\f.                                     Fi\t. 3 r\fpr\fs\fntation of translation information in OMBI-\bMF Bilingual Ext\fnsion  W\f b\fli\fv\f that th\f \bMF standard should b\f mor\f \fxplicit about th\f r\fpr\fs\fntation of languag\f d\fp\fndant usag\f contrasts. In contrast to multilingual data, most \fxisting bilingual l\fxical data contain rath\fr subtl\f and fin\f-grain\fd information about th\f d\fgr\f\f of translation \fquival\fnc\f b\ftw\f\fn th\f words of th\f involv\fd languag\fs and w\f f\f\fl that it is important to b\f abl\f to r\fpr\fs\fnt this information in a standardis\fd way. If th\fs\f contrasts cannot b\f includ\fd in on\f of th\f curr\fnt \bMF \fxt\fnsions, this is an indication that a s\fparat\f \fxt\fnsion for bilingual N\bP l\fxicons is n\f\fd\fd.

sections.title: 5. Metadata
paragraphs: It is cl\far that conv\frsion to a standard only contribut\fs to th\f t\fchnical asp\fcts of th\f availability of th\f data; th\f findability, id\fntification and linguistic charact\frisation ar\f of \fqual importanc\f. \th\fr\ffor\f good m\ftadata ar\f crucial. Esp\fcially, within th\f fram\fwork of th\f Dutch H\b\t ag\fncy, m\ftadata ar\f \fss\fntial for archiving, distribution and maint\fnanc\f of th\f data. \th\f m\ftadata that w\f us\f ar\f bas\fd on a combination of curr\fnt standards (IMDI, O\bAC, DC) as non\f of th\f availabl\f propos\fd standards s\f\fm\fd to provid\f an un\fquivocal tr\fatm\fnt of m\ftadata at th\f l\fv\fls w\f ar\f int\fr\fst\fd in (i.\f. archiving, id\fntification and linguistic charact\frisation). In our opinion, th\f availabl\f m\ftadata ar\f not g\far\fd sp\fcifically \fnough to th\f id\fntification and linguistic charact\frisation of bilingual l\fxical r\fsourc\fs. For instanc\f, IMDI do\fs not distinguish b\ftw\f\fn monolingual, bilingual and multilingual l\fxica b\fcaus\f it claims that bilingual and multilingual l\fxica can b\f brok\fn down into monolingual l\fxica. Cons\fqu\fntly, th\f possibility to indicat\f that th\f bilingual r\fsourc\fs contain\fd a lot of information on translation \fquival\fnc\f b\ftw\f\fn th\f languag\fs, was missing and has b\f\fn add\fd to our m\ftadata. sections.title: 6. Conc\fu\bion
paragraphs: In this pap\fr, w\f discuss\fd som\f of th\f issu\fs involv\fd in th\f standardisation of a s\ft of bilingual l\fxical r\fsourc\fs according to \bMF. \to b\f abl\f to r\fpr\fs\fnt th\f fin\f-grain\fd s\fmantic and pragmatic distinctions availabl\f in our sourc\f data (d\fgr\f\f of translation \fquival\fnc\f, pr\ff\frr\fd \fquival\fnts, \ftc.) w\f propos\fd an \bMF \fxt\fnsion sp\fcifically for bilingual l\fxicons. \th\f mod\fl is a compromis\f of th\f \bMF \fxt\fnsions for MRDs and for N\bP multilingual l\fxicons. Du\f to th\f sp\fcific natur\f of monolingual, bilingual and multilingual l\fxical r\fsourc\fs, w\f b\fli\fv\f that it is important for standardisation \ffforts to mak\f a distinction b\ftw\f\fn th\fm and to provid\f s\fparat\f standards.
